SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Which quotation describes the setting of the story?

A.Choice: “In a twinkling, he jumped down from his bed to look on the chair standing near.” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “There, he found a new suit, a new hat, and a pair of shoes.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “The Marionette opened the purse to find the money, and behold—there were fifty gold coins!” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “The bright face of a tall boy looked at him with wideawake blue eyes, dark brown hair and happy, smiling lips.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which quotation from the story shows why Pinocchio was happy?

A.Choice: “... Pinocchio, instead of going to bed at ten o'clock, waited until midnight, ...” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “... he saw that he was no longer a Marionette, ...” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “... he found a new suit, a new hat, and a pair of shoes.” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: “... he put his hands in his pockets and pulled out a little leather purse...” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 18.
:ibox:“How r͟i͟d͟i͟c͟u͟l͟o͟u͟s I was as a Marionette!”
Which word means the same as r͟i͟d͟i͟c͟u͟l͟o͟u͟s as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: boring

B.Choice: complete

C.Choice: different

D.Choice: silly

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Which quotation describes how Pinocchio's behavior affected the household in the story?

A.Choice: “'Father, Father, what has happened? Tell me if you can,' ...” (paragraph 11)

B.Choice: “'This sudden change in our house is all your doing, my dear Pinocchio,' ...” (paragraph 12)

C.Choice: “'I wonder where the old Pinocchio of wood has hidden himself?'” (paragraph 15)

D.Choice: “'And how happy I am, now that I have become a real boy!'” (paragraph 18)

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Make connections between the text of a story or drama and a visual or oral presentation of the text, identifying where each version reflects specific descriptions and directions in the text.
Content: Which paragraph does the picture help the reader understand?

A.Choice: paragraph 3

B.Choice: paragraph 14

C.Choice: paragraph 16

D.Choice: paragraph 18

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Select T͟H͟R͟E͟E͟ statements that should be included in a summary of the story.

A.Choice: Pinocchio was a marionette.

B.Choice: Pinocchio lived with his father.

C.Choice: Pinocchio was changed to a boy.

D.Choice: Pinocchio's father was an old man.

E.Choice: Pinocchio found gold coins in his purse.

F.Choice: Pinocchio learned to make good choices.

G.Choice: Pinocchio saw the wooden boy leaning against a chair.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 4.
:ibox:He looked all about him and instead of the usual walls of straw, he found himself in a beautifully f͟u͟r͟n͟i͟s͟h͟e͟d little room, the prettiest he had ever seen.
What does the word f͟u͟r͟n͟i͟s͟h͟e͟d mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: available

B.Choice: circled

C.Choice: cleaned

D.Choice: decorated

SubTopics: Explain major differences between poems, drama, and prose, and refer to the structural elements of poems (e.g., verse, rhythm, meter) and drama (e.g., casts of characters, settings, descriptions, dialogue, stage directions) when writing or speaking about a text.
Content: How would the excerpt from The Adventures of Pinocchio be different if it were written as a play?

A.Choice: It would have directions that tell the father what to do while Pinocchio is asleep.

B.Choice: It would have directions that tell what the Marionette does as he falls on the floor.

C.Choice: It would have directions that tell the Fairy what to say about Pinocchio as he is dreaming.

D.Choice: It would have directions that tell what Pinocchio does when he wakes and realizes he has changed.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Read the summary of the excerpt from The Adventures of Pinocchio.
:ibox:Pinocchio is rewarded and forgiven for his past behavior because of his kind heart. He is given new clothes, a leather purse with money, and a real body to replace his wooden body.
Select the detail that BEST completes the summary.

A.Choice: Pinocchio and his father decide to decorate a picture frame together.

B.Choice: Pinocchio and his father are able to enjoy a home filled with happiness.

C.Choice: Pinocchio and his father find the old Pinocchio leaning against a chair.

D.Choice: Pinocchio and his father realize how happy Pinocchio was as a wooden boy.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 10.
:ibox:He ran into the next room, and there stood Geppetto, grown years younger overnight, s͟p͟i͟c͟k͟ ͟a͟n͟d͟ ͟s͟p͟a͟n in his new clothes and gay as a lark in the morning.
Which word would BEST replace s͟p͟i͟c͟k͟ ͟a͟n͟d͟ ͟s͟p͟a͟n as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: alive

B.Choice: kind

C.Choice: neat

D.Choice: slim

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: What is a theme of the story?

A.Choice: Things come easily to those who wait.

B.Choice: Dreams come true no matter what a person does.

C.Choice: When people act with kindness, they are rewarded.

D.Choice: In order to get what you want, all you have to do is ask.

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: What is the purpose of the first two paragraphs in “Kylie's Fossil Find”?

A.Choice: They describe the first event in a sequence of events.

B.Choice: They explain the effects of Kylie's actions on her family.

C.Choice: They describe Kylie and compare her to the paleontologists.

D.Choice: They explain a problem that will be solved in the rest of the passage.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: Which quotation from the passage BEST supports the claim that fossils can be preserved for long periods of time?

A.Choice: “Every time it rained, the butte eroded and more of the fossil was exposed.” (paragraph 10)

B.Choice: “Paleontologists soon realized that this was a very rare saber tooth cat skull!” (paragraph 11)

C.Choice: “The hard limestone protected the fossils for millions of years...” (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: “It took them three days to carefully dig around the fossilized bones... !” (paragraph 14)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret information presented visually, orally, or quantitatively (e.g., in charts, graphs, diagrams, time lines, animations, or interactive elements on Web pages) and explain how the information contributes to an understanding of the text in which it appears.
Content: What does the picture in “Kylie's Fossil Find” help the reader understand about the fossil discovery?

A.Choice: important details around the map area

B.Choice: important details about the picnic table

C.Choice: important details that include what the item looked like

D.Choice: important details that include where the item was found

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 10.
:ibox:Every time it rained, the butte e͟r͟o͟d͟e͟d and more of the fossil was exposed.
What is the meaning of the word e͟r͟o͟d͟e͟d as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: grew

B.Choice: dug up

C.Choice: protected

D.Choice: washed away

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: Which sentence explains what happened after the fossil was first found?

A.Choice: The fossil was carefully excavated so that it could later be prepared in the lab.

B.Choice: The fossil was carefully examined so that it could be pictured in the newspaper.

C.Choice: The fossil was surrounded by limestone so it could be protected from the elements.

D.Choice: The fossil was shiny and white because every time it rained, more of the fossil was exposed.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which TWO quotations support the idea that uncovering fossils requires patience?

A.Choice: “While they were exploring the Badlands, Kylie and her mom noticed something on the ground that looked a little unusual.” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “Paleontologists checked on the fossil find throughout the summer.” (paragraph 9)

C.Choice: “Every time it rained, the butte eroded and more of the fossil was exposed.” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “The hard limestone protected the fossils for millions of years before Kylie found them.” (paragraph 12)

E.Choice: “It took them three days to carefully dig around the fossilized bones and remove them from the butte!” (paragraph 14)

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: :ibox:The following problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Read the sentence from paragraph 13.
:ibox:Paleontologists carefully e͟x͟c͟a͟v͟a͟t͟e͟d the fossils.
Which word means the same as e͟x͟c͟a͟v͟a͟t͟e͟d as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: examined

B.Choice: plastered

C.Choice: protected

D.Choice: uncovered

Content: Which paragraph further explains the fossils being excavated, as the word is defined in Part A?

A.Choice: paragraph 8

B.Choice: paragraph 11

C.Choice: paragraph 14

D.Choice: paragraph 16

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 11.
:ibox:Skulls from saber tooth cats are usually broken or f͟r͟a͟g͟m͟e͟n͟t͟e͟d.
Which TWO words mean the same as f͟r͟a͟g͟m͟e͟n͟t͟e͟d as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: cracked

B.Choice: fixed

C.Choice: removed

D.Choice: shattered

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Read the following summary.

:ibox:The Badlands National Park had a junior ranger program during the summer. The girl and her mom noticed something and thought it might be a fossil. Over a period of time, paleontologists carefully removed the fossil and studied it.
Which statement should be included in the summary?

A.Choice: Kylie and her family learned about fossils.

B.Choice: The fossil was covered in limestone.

C.Choice: Sometimes the skulls are broken.

D.Choice: Fossils are white and shiny.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: :ibox:The following problem has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
At the beginning of the story, how do the little crickets feel about having to wake up?

A.Choice: The little crickets are excited about joining their cousins.

B.Choice: The little crickets would rather sleep than chirp all night.

C.Choice: The little crickets want to get up and listen to a story.

D.Choice: The little crickets want to show that they are good.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'Some of our cousins are already singing, and it will soon be dark.'” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “'Oh dear! Why do we have to get up?'” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “'Oh, mother, is it a story?'” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “'We are good little crickets, aren't we, mother?' ...” (paragraph 22)

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Select TWO words that BEST describe Dame Cricket.

A.Choice: angry

B.Choice: caring

C.Choice: noisy

D.Choice: patient

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 2.
:ibox:But the little crickets snuggled under the bedclothes just as if they did not hear their mother's words.
What can the reader infer about the little crickets?

A.Choice: The little crickets did not wake up on time.

B.Choice: The little crickets were ready to get out of bed.

C.Choice: The little crickets did not want to get out of bed.

D.Choice: The little crickets were snuggled under the bedclothes.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 10.
:ibox:“'You all have fine­looking throats, as fine as ever crickets had, and yet our singing is very f͟a͟i͟n͟t; there is not as much volume to it as in the old days.'”
Which TWO words mean the same as f͟a͟i͟n͟t as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: clear

B.Choice: loud

C.Choice: quiet

D.Choice: soft

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).
Content: :ibox:“Oh, mother, is it a story?” asked all the little crickets, j͟u͟m͟p͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟o͟u͟t͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟b͟e͟d͟ ͟w͟i͟t͟h͟ ͟a͟ ͟b͟o͟u͟n͟d and gathering about their mother.
What does the phrase j͟u͟m͟p͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟o͟u͟t͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟b͟e͟d͟ ͟w͟i͟t͟h͟ ͟a͟ ͟b͟o͟u͟n͟d tell the reader about how the crickets got out of bed?

A.Choice: The little crickets got out of bed quickly and with excitement.

B.Choice: The little crickets got out of bed quietly and with caution.

C.Choice: The little crickets got out of bed curiously and with fear.

D.Choice: The little crickets got out of bed slowly and with care.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Which word describes a trait of the little crickets in the story?

A.Choice: angry

B.Choice: different

C.Choice: frustrated

D.Choice: respectful

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence should be included in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: The little crickets dressed quietly.

B.Choice: The little crickets' cousins were already outside singing.

C.Choice: The little crickets had to put on little backpacks and little brown suits.

D.Choice: The little crickets realized the importance of getting up when they were called.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which statement describes a theme of the story?

A.Choice: Resting is best done at night.

B.Choice: Being young is better than being old.

C.Choice: Doing what one is told brings rewards.

D.Choice: Learning from the past leads to good decisions.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which quotation from the passage “What Was the Apollo Program?” describes one duty of the Apollo Program?

A.Choice: “The first four flights tested the equipment used in the Apollo Program.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Once the spacecraft reached the moon, the two modules separated from each other.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “On the last three missions, astronauts drove on the moon with the lunar rover.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “These missions made it possible to explore more distant worlds further in the future.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 9 of “What Was the Apollo Program?”
:ibox:In 1961, President John F. Kennedy c͟h͟a͟l͟l͟e͟n͟g͟e͟d͟ the nation to land astronauts on the moon by the end of the decade.
What does the word c͟h͟a͟l͟l͟e͟n͟g͟e͟d mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: told to do something

B.Choice: dared to do something

C.Choice: made it harder to do something

D.Choice: questioned about doing something

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: In the passage “What Was the Apollo Program?”, how does the information in paragraph 9 support the idea that space travel is important?

A.Choice: It explains how the Apollo Program happened in stages.

B.Choice: It explains how scientific research on the moon is important.

C.Choice: It explains how space travel to other planets became possible.

D.Choice: It explains how astronauts drove special vehicles to explore the moon.

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain- specific words and phrases, including those that signal precise actions, emotions, or states of being (e.g., quizzed, whined, stammered) and that are basic to a particular topic (e.g., wildlife, conservation, and endangered when discussing animal preservation).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 4 of “What Was the Apollo Program?”
:ibox:The first manned m͟i͟s͟s͟i͟o͟n to the moon was Apollo 8.
What is the meaning of the word m͟i͟s͟s͟i͟o͟n as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: astronaut

B.Choice: exploration

C.Choice: orbit

D.Choice: rover

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: According to “What Was the Apollo Program?”, what was the purpose of the first four Apollo flights?

A.Choice: to collect moon rocks to study on Earth

B.Choice: to conduct scientific research on the moon

C.Choice: to help astronauts get used to being in space for long periods of time

D.Choice: to test the equipment that would be used to take astronauts to the moon

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: :ibox:The following problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Read the sentence from paragraph 1 of the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon.
:ibox:Neil climbed out first and d͟e͟s͟c͟e͟n͟d͟e͟d Eagle's ladder to the Moon's surface.
What is the meaning of the word d͟e͟s͟c͟e͟n͟d͟e͟d as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: to raise

B.Choice: to lower

C.Choice: to fall off

D.Choice: to extend out

Content: Which quotation helps the reader to understand the meaning of d͟e͟s͟c͟e͟n͟d͟e͟d as it is used in Part A?

A.Choice: “... put on our space suits.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “... climbed down the ladder...” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “... stretched in all directions.” (paragraph 2)

D.Choice: “... in the sky overhead— ...” (paragraph 3)

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: What does Buzz mean by the observation “Magnificent desolation” as it is used in paragraph 2 of the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon?

A.Choice: He saw a complete lack of color on Earth and its continents.

B.Choice: He saw so little color in space that he compared it to velvet.

C.Choice: He saw a complete lack of color as he descended the ladder.

D.Choice: He saw so little color in space that he compared it to the rocks and craters.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence summarizes the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon?

A.Choice: The passage describes what Earth looked like.

B.Choice: The passage describes the landscape of the moon.

C.Choice: The passage describes the astronauts putting on their space suits.

D.Choice: The passage describes the astronauts' first moments on the moon.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 2 of the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon.
:ibox:The shadows and the sky above were as black as the blackest velvet I had ever seen.
Why is the sky described as being “as black as the blackest velvet”?

A.Choice: to illustrate that the moon was bright

B.Choice: to elaborate on the openness of space

C.Choice: to emphasize how truly dark the sky was

D.Choice: to show that the sky was a beautiful sight to see

SubTopics: Compare and contrast a firsthand and secondhand account of the same event or topic; describe the differences in focus and the information provided.
Content: How is the information in “What Was the Apollo Program?” different from the information in the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon?

A.Choice: The excerpt from Reaching for the Moon tells the date that the astronauts landed on the moon, and “What Was the Apollo Program?” does not.

B.Choice: “What Was the Apollo Program?” gives a description of how Earth looked from the moon, and the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon does not.

C.Choice: The excerpt from Reaching for the Moon tells about the personal experience of Buzz Aldrin landing on the moon, and “What Was the Apollo Program?” does not.

D.Choice: “What Was the Apollo Program?” gives us the sequence in which the astronauts got off the Eagle spacecraft, and the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon does not.

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: How is the structure of “What Was the Apollo Program?” different from the structure of the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon?

A.Choice: “What Was the Apollo Program?” uses chronological order, while the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon uses description.

B.Choice: “What Was the Apollo Program?” uses description, while the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon uses chronological order.

C.Choice: “What Was the Apollo Program?” uses problem and solution, while the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon uses cause and effect.

D.Choice: “What Was the Apollo Program?” uses cause and effect, while the excerpt from Reaching for the Moon uses problem and solution.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Integrate information from two texts on the same topic in order to write or speak about the subject knowledgeably.
Content: Read the quotation from BOTH passages.
:ibox:That's one small step for (a) man, one giant leap for mankind.
Based on the quotation, what inference can be made about man's first walk on the moon?

A.Choice: The astronauts left giant footprints on the moon.

B.Choice: The first walk on the moon was important for all people.

C.Choice: Neil Armstrong took small steps when walking on the moon.

D.Choice: One man stepped on the moon while another man leapt onto the moon.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: Read the following prompt and write your complete response in the space provided.

:ibox:You have read the passage “Seed Travel.” Write an essay explaining how the author organizes the passage to describe how and why a seed travels. Be sure to use details from the passage to explain how the author structures the passage to describe how and why seeds travel.

Your writing will be scored based on the development of ideas, organization of writing, and language convention of grammar, usage, and mechanics.
Write your response for the prompt in the space below.
